subject: Add meson build
commitMessage:
Add meson build

This commit is to add meson.build.
And later, we will remove Autotools and replace it with meson build.

Signed-off-by: George Liu <liuxiwei@inspur.com>
Change-Id: I3107491093a6b69f966bab6eeb4f2d7581bfa186

Patch Set 7:

Does everyone have any comments?
Change has been successfully merged by Andrew Jeffery
Can we follow up and move these to a header file?  There's not much good reason to have them in meson, imho.

Since you're not using any of the tools out of sdbusplus, you can do the normal dependency:

sdbusplus_dep = dependency(
    'sdbusplus',
    fallback: [ 'sdbusplus', 'sdbusplus_dep' ],
)

Please use consistent tabs/spaces throughout.

I prefer these lists sorted.
This should not be necessary with C++20 (or even C++17).
Why is this necessary?  Sounds like test cases are reading or modifying files from the current directory?  This probably needs to be fixed.  Maybe a follow up.
I'd like this in a separate commit.

Yeah, I pushed a new patch
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-sysfs/+/43342
I would have preferred we dropped config.h in a separate, prior commit to changing the build system...
Are we intentionally upgrading from 17 to 20 in the same commit that we're replacing the build system?
Why not define a subproject for systemd also? Should be straight-forward as it uses meson?
configure.ac installs into sbindir. Maybe we should be bug-compatible until we remove autotools? Or, switch autotools to install into bindir first in a separate commit before adding meson.

Yes, I pushed a new patch to change the installation directory in the Makefile.am file.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-sysfs/+/43344

I'd prefer this as:

 if build_tests.enabled() or build_tests.auto()

Sorry, TBH, Here is what I copied from the phosphor-led-manager repo.
Updated.
Surely we want to fix this at a given revision for reproducible builds.
Well, probably whatever commit ID HEAD points to right now? 😊
Surely we want to fix this at a given revision for reproducible builds.
Whatever commit ID HEAD currently points to?

Should be the latest commit ID `33458d4432a8323616622881f314a73cf0b04d97`
https://mesonbuild.com/Wrap-dependency-system-manual.html#specific-to-vcsbased-wraps
Surely we want to fix this at a given revision for reproducible builds.
Sure, Could you tell me which revison?
Whatever commit ID HEAD currently points to?
Again, this is a separate problem to meson.
This looks inspired by the switch to c++20? I'd prefer that is a separate commit prior to adding a new build system.

Yes, I pushed a new patch for it
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-sysfs/+/43342
Real nit-pick, but this looks misaligned with respect to the `if` above.
Why is this pointing to a specific commit instead of HEAD ?.. using HEAD is the norm that I have seen all through.

@George, please put these back to HEAD.  I had a discussion with AndrewJ on Discord today to confirm this is the right direction for the project.  I'll be responsible for writing up a "how to meson" in docs to formalize documentation that subprojects should use HEAD for referencing other OpenBMC projects.

Yeah, sorry for leading you astray here George.

I don't like how meson behaves, but we probably should have it behave consistently across the OpenBMC repos.
same comment as previous file ( HEAD )

I'm not seeing any systemd header files being used by this codebase, so there shouldn't be need for a direct systemd dependency.  There is an implicit / indirect dependency on it that sdbusplus brings in, but you don't need to express that.

(Maybe place we have this listed in the autotools files has always been wrong...)
this line here conflicts with Patrick's -1 on /usr/bin . So we need to arrive at some consensus on that before this can go in.
Yeah, But I think using `/usr/bin` makes sense.

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-led-sysfs/blob/master/configure.ac#L127

should the devpath be another meson configurable option ?
I see that the dev path is hardcoded in another commit, nevermind.
Yeah, We don’t have any reason to change DEVPATH, so we can hardcoded
I saw many repos use `t`, so I have no plans to change the value of this variable.

Having a readable variable names than just a single letter would help some one to easily understand the code when they look at it.some thing like "foreach test : tests", "test.underscorify()" is lot better than using "t","t.underscorify()"

> I saw many repos use `t`,
lets take good things from other repos, not these.

Its not a big change as such,but i would leave it to the maintainers to decide.

Sure
I will update when the https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-sysfs/+/43344 commit is vote passed.

Currently, configure.ac as --enable-oe-sdk.. May I know where is that covered ?.. When I made the last change, just the "tests" did not work and I ended up putting oe-sdk support for GTEST.

Were you able to run GTEST with just this ?
It should just work because of the subprojects - meson can build all the dependencies itself.

> It should just work because of the subprojects - meson can build all the dependencies itself.

+1

> Were you able to run GTEST with just this ?

I think you may confuse meson and autotools compilation method

For autotools:
```
1. ./bootstrap.sh
2. ./configure ${CONFIGURE_FLAGS} --enable-oe-sdk
3. make
4. make check
```

For meson
```
1. meson build(because test is enabled by default) or meson -Dtest=enabled build
2. ninja -C build test
```

Does make sense?

I am not confused. All I am saying is this : 

In Auto tools, I just could not see how to enable tests. However, I saw "test" was getting built default. However, `make check` always failed. So, I am asking if GTEST worked fine in this method ?

You can go look at the CI run:
